Not all water parameters are created equal. Based on current scientific consensus (including studies from the Specialty Coffee Association - SCA - and experts like Scott Rao), water quality for coffee is primarily determined by two factors:


1. Alkalinity (the most important factor)

Think of alkalinity as a "buffer" that neutralizes acids. It has the most direct impact on the taste of your coffee.

  • Very high alkalinity: Over-neutralizes the bright, tasty acids in the coffee, resulting in a "flat," "dull," or "lifeless" brew.
  • Very low alkalinity: Offers no protection against corrosion in your machines and can result in an overly "acidic" or "sour" coffee.

2. Total Hardness (Calcium and Magnesium)

Hardness is crucial for extraction. Calcium and magnesium ions bind to flavor compounds in the coffee grounds and pull them into the water. Additionally, hardness is the main factor in scale buildup (limescale) in your equipment.

  • Very high hardness: Causes rapid scale buildup, requiring constant maintenance.
  • Very low hardness: The water lacks "extraction power," resulting in a "weak" or "under-extracted" coffee.

pH, although monitored, is considered less impactful on the final taste than alkalinity.

You will notice that TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) and Sodium are part of our analysis. We are being transparent about how we handle them.


The "Ideal" TDS Myth

Older standards (like the 2011 SCAA chart) popularized the idea of an "ideal" TDS of 150 mg/L. However, more recent studies from the SCA (like the 2018 handbook) and industry experts are clear: TDS, by itself, is not a good indicator of quality.


Why? A TDS of 150 can be composed of ideal minerals (calcium and bicarbonate) or unwanted minerals (like table salt). The total number doesn\'t tell the whole story.


Our (Honest) Approach

We include TDS and Sodium in our score because we know they are a popular concern and appear on many water reports. We use the 2011 SCAA reference ranges to evaluate them.

However, to ensure your score reflects what truly matters for taste, TDS and Sodium have a very low weight in our final calculation. They serve as "tie-breakers" but will never define whether your water is good or bad.

There is no "magic number" or single standard for perfect water. The ideal water for espresso may be slightly different from that for filter coffee. Therefore, our system is based on optimal ranges and importance weights.


Our scoring system synthesizes data from multiple sources (including various SCA standards and expert research) to create an "app philosophy" that prioritizes flavor and equipment safety.


The Weighted Calculation

Your final score (from 0 to 100) is a weighted average. This means we prioritize what matters most:


  • Alkalinity: Receives the highest weight (50% of the score).
  • Total Hardness: Receives a medium weight (30% of the score).
  • TDS and Sodium: Receive a minimal weight (10% each).

This ensures that water with great alkalinity and hardness will always get a good score, even if the TDS is outside the popular "ideal." And conversely, water with a TDS of 150 will receive a low grade if the alkalinity (the most important factor) is poor.

How the Calculator Works (PPM per Drop)

The Water Optimizer (Premium feature) calculates how many drops of each mineral you need to add to your water to reach the ideal quality ranges for coffee.


How the New Philosophy Works

Unlike old methods that sought a "magic number," the optimizer works with acceptable ranges based on what truly matters for taste:

  • Alkalinity (30-50 ppm): The most important factor. Controls the beverage\'s acid balance.
  • Total Hardness (50-90 ppm): Defines the water\'s extraction power. Comes from Calcium and Magnesium.
  • Sodium (0-10 ppm) & TDS (100-180 ppm): Monitored, but with less weight in the calculation.

The Drop Calculation

The app aims to hit the center of the ideal ranges, not a fixed value. For example:

  • If your water has 30 ppm Hardness, the app suggests drops to reach ~70 ppm (center of 50-90).
  • If it\'s already at 80 ppm, you will see the message "‚úì Hardness is already in the ideal range!"
